protocol_name: Complete Sample Protocol Detailing the Seeding, Stimulation, and Detection of the NIH3T3 Cellular Response to Acidic Fibroblast Growth Factor (aFGF-1)
protocol_name_html: Complete Sample Protocol Detailing the Seeding, Stimulation, and Detection of the NIH3T3 Cellular Response to Acidic Fibroblast Growth Factor (aFGF-1)
description:
Developed for:

 

Aerius,
Odyssey® Classic,

Odyssey CLx, and

Odyssey Sa

Imaging Systems
warning: See SDS for safety warnings and hazards.
guidelines:
Required Reagents

LI-COR Reagents

  • IRDye® 800CW goat anti-mouse secondary antibodies (LI-COR P/N 925-32210 or 926-32210)

  • IRDye 680RD goat anti-rabbit secondary antibodies (LI-COR P/N 925-68071 or 926-68071)

  • Odyssey® Blocking Buffer (LI-COR P/N 927-40000 or 927-50000)

 

Additional Reagents

  • 1X PBS wash buffer

  • Tissue culture reagents (serum, DMEM, trypsin, 1X PBS)

  • Poly-D-Lysine coated 96-well microplate clear/black or clear (Corning P/N 354640

    or 354461)

  • Heparin (CALBIOCHEM®, P/N 375097)

  • Acidic Fibroblast Growth Factor (Upstate Group Inc., P/N 01-116)

  • Primary antibodies

  • 20% Tween® 20

  • 37% formaldehyde

  • 10% Triton® X-100

SPECIAL NOTE: NIH3T3 cells do not adhere strongly to TC-treated plates, resulting in the need for poly-D-lysine-coated plates in this assay. However, even with lysine-coated plates, the adherence of cells remains relatively weak compared to other cell lines.
 
Be extremely cautious and delicate in handling plates and pipetting when washing, removing, and adding solutions to avoid detaching the cells.
 
 
Experimental Considerations
 

Establish the specificity of the primary antibody by screening plate-like lysates through Western blotting and detection on an Odyssey instrument. If significant non-specific binding is present, choose alternative primary antibodies to avoid results with non-specific signal detection.

 

Proper selection of microplates can significantly affect results, as each plate has its own characteristics, including well depth, plate autofluorescence, and well-to-well signal crossover. Use the following general considerations for microplate selection.

  • In-Cell Western analyses use detection at the well surface with no liquid present. This results in minimal well-to-well signal spread, allowing the use of both clear and black-sided plates with clear bottoms. Do not use plates with white walls, since autofluorescence from the white surface will create significant noise.

  • Protect plates from light before imaging to ensure highest sensitivity. When storing plates after imaging, the plates should remain protected from light at 4 °C. 

  • Focus Offset Optimization – If plates other than those recommended are used, the focus offset can be determined empirically by scanning a plate containing experimental and control samples using the following focus offset settings.


Use the same intensity settings for each scan. After reviewing the scans, use the focus offset with the highest signal-to-noise ratio for experiments. The actual minimum and maximum focus offset will vary with each instrument. Alternatively, the plate manufacturer can be consulted to obtain the measured distance from the skirt bottom to the bottom of the plate. 

 

All Aerius and Odyssey® Imaging Systems (excluding Odyssey Fc) require microplates that have a maximum 4.0 mm distance from the base of the microplate to the target detection area of the plate (actual maximum focus offset varies with each Aerius and Odyssey Sa instrument, and is found by choosing Settings > System Administration, then clicking Scanner Information). When using plates specified for In-Cell Western assays, the recommended focus offset is 3.5 mm or higher.

  • Intensity Setting Optimization -

 

  • Protect plates from light before imaging to ensure highest sensitivity. When storing plates after imaging, the plates should remain protected from light at 4 °C.

 

IV. Experimental Results

components.data: Allow NIH3T3 (ATCC; CRL-1555) cell growth in a T75 flask using standard tissue culture procedures until cells reach near confluency (~1.5 x 107 cells; DMEM, 10% FBS; Gibco®)
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Allow NIH3T3 (ATCC; CRL-1555) cell growth in a T75 flask using standard tissue culture procedures until cells reach near confluency (~1.5 x 107 cells; DMEM, 10% FBS; Gibco®)

components.data: Remove growth media, wash cells with sterile 1X PBS, and trypsinize cells for displacement.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove growth media, wash cells with sterile 1X PBS, and trypsinize cells for displacement.

components.data: Neutralize displaced cells with culture media and clarify by centrifugation (500 x g).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Neutralize displaced cells with culture media and clarify by centrifugation (500 x g).

components.data:
Remove supernatant and disrupt the cell pellet manually by hand tapping the collection tube.

Do not pipet or vortex during pellet disruption to maintain cell integrity.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Remove supernatant and disrupt the cell pellet manually by hand tapping the collection tube.

Do not pipet or vortex during pellet disruption to maintain cell integrity.

components.data: Resuspend cells in 20 mL of complete media and count cells using a hemacytometer.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Resuspend cells in 20 mL of complete media and count cells using a hemacytometer.

components.data: Reconstitute cells and dilute in 40 mL of complete media so that 75,000 cells/mL is achieved (2 plates x 96 wells x 200 μL/well = ~40 mL).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Reconstitute cells and dilute in 40 mL of complete media so that 75,000 cells/mL is achieved (2 plates x 96 wells x 200 μL/well = ~40 mL).

components.data: Manually mix the cell suspension thoroughly.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Manually mix the cell suspension thoroughly.

components.data: Under sterile conditions, dispense 200 μL of the cell suspension per well into a SIGMA-Screen™ Poly-D-Lysine 96-well microplate (15,000 cells plated per well).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Under sterile conditions, dispense 200 μL of the cell suspension per well into a SIGMA-Screen™ Poly-D-Lysine 96-well microplate (15,000 cells plated per well).

components.data: Incubate cells and monitor cell density until 70% confluency is achieved (about 24 hours).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Incubate cells and monitor cell density until 70% confluency is achieved (about 24 hours).

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 9 of Complete Sample Protocol Detailing the Seeding, Stimulation, and Detection of the NIH3T3 Cellular Response to Acidic Fibroblast Growth Factor (aFGF-1)
source_data.protocol_name: Complete Sample Protocol Detailing the Seeding, Stimulation, and Detection of the NIH3T3 Cellular Response to Acidic Fibroblast Growth Factor (aFGF-1)
source_data.protocol_name_html: Complete Sample Protocol Detailing the Seeding, Stimulation, and Detection of the NIH3T3 Cellular Response to Acidic Fibroblast Growth Factor (aFGF-1)
source_data.annotation: 70% confluency is very important. 90 to 100% confluent cells are certain to detach during washing.
source_data.thread_text: 70% confluency is very important. 90 to 100% confluent cells are certain to detach during washing.
source_data.body: 70% confluency is very important. 90 to 100% confluent cells are certain to detach during washing.

components.data: Warm serum-free media (DMEM; Gibco) to 37°C.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Warm serum-free media (DMEM; Gibco) to 37°C.

components.data: Carefully remove media and inhibitor from plate wells by aspiration or manual displacement.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Carefully remove media and inhibitor from plate wells by aspiration or manual displacement.

components.data:
• Add either serum-free media for resting cells (mock) or serum-free media with serial concentrations of aFGF-1 ranging from 0.2 to 100 ng/mL, combined with 10 μg/mL heparin for activated cells.
  • Use 100 μL of resting/activation media per well.
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
• Add either serum-free media for resting cells (mock) or serum-free media with serial concentrations of aFGF-1 ranging from 0.2 to 100 ng/mL, combined with 10 μg/mL heparin for activated cells.
  • Use 100 μL of resting/activation media per well.

components.data: Allow incubation at 37°C for 7.5 minutes.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Allow incubation at 37°C for 7.5 minutes.

components.data: Remove activation or stimulation media manually or by aspiration. Immediately fix cells with 4% formaldehyde in 1X PBS for 20 minutes at room temperature. Detailed in steps 15-17.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove activation or stimulation media manually or by aspiration. Immediately fix cells with 4% formaldehyde in 1X PBS for 20 minutes at room temperature. Detailed in steps 15-17.

components.data: Prepare fresh Fixing Solution as follows:
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Prepare fresh Fixing Solution as follows:

components.data: Using a multi-channel pipettor, add 150 μL of fresh Fixing Solution (room temperature solution, RT). Make sure to add the solution down the sides of the wells carefully to avoid detaching the cells from the well bottom.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Using a multi-channel pipettor, add 150 μL of fresh Fixing Solution (room temperature solution, RT). Make sure to add the solution down the sides of the wells carefully to avoid detaching the cells from the well bottom.

components.data: Allow incubation on bench top for 20 minutes at RT with no shaking.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Allow incubation on bench top for 20 minutes at RT with no shaking.

components.data: Wash five times with 1X PBS containing 0.1% Triton® X-100 (cell permeabilization) for 5 minutes per wash. Detailed in steps 19-35.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Wash five times with 1X PBS containing 0.1% Triton® X-100 (cell permeabilization) for 5 minutes per wash. Detailed in steps 19-35.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 18 of Complete Sample Protocol Detailing the Seeding, Stimulation, and Detection of the NIH3T3 Cellular Response to Acidic Fibroblast Growth Factor (aFGF-1)
source_data.protocol_name: Complete Sample Protocol Detailing the Seeding, Stimulation, and Detection of the NIH3T3 Cellular Response to Acidic Fibroblast Growth Factor (aFGF-1)

source_data.annotation: Do not allow cells/wells to become dry during washing. Immediately add the next wash after manual disposal.
source_data.thread_text: Do not allow cells/wells to become dry during washing. Immediately add the next wash after manual disposal.
source_data.body: Do not allow cells/wells to become dry during washing. Immediately add the next wash after manual disposal.

components.data: Prepare Triton Washing Solution as follows:
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Prepare Triton Washing Solution as follows:

components.data: Remove Fixing Solution to an appropriate waste container (contains formaldehyde).
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove Fixing Solution to an appropriate waste container (contains formaldehyde).

components.data: Using a multi-channel pipettor, add 200 μL of Triton Washing Solution (RT). Make sure to add the solution down the sides of the wells carefully to avoid detaching the cells from the well bottom. (wash 1/5)
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Using a multi-channel pipettor, add 200 μL of Triton Washing Solution (RT). Make sure to add the solution down the sides of the wells carefully to avoid detaching the cells from the well bottom. (wash 1/5)

components.data: Allow wash to shake on a rotator for 5 minutes at RT. (wash 1/5)
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Allow wash to shake on a rotator for 5 minutes at RT. (wash 1/5)

components.data: Using a multi-channel pipettor, add 200 μL of Triton Washing Solution (RT). Make sure to add the solution down the sides of the wells carefully to avoid detaching the cells from the well bottom. (wash 2/5)
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Using a multi-channel pipettor, add 200 μL of Triton Washing Solution (RT). Make sure to add the solution down the sides of the wells carefully to avoid detaching the cells from the well bottom. (wash 2/5)

components.data: Using a multi-channel pipettor, block cells/wells by adding 150μL of Odyssey® Blocking Buffer to each well. Add the solution carefully by pipetting down the sides of the wells to avoid detaching the cells.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Using a multi-channel pipettor, block cells/wells by adding 150μL of Odyssey® Blocking Buffer to each well. Add the solution carefully by pipetting down the sides of the wells to avoid detaching the cells.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 24 of Complete Sample Protocol Detailing the Seeding, Stimulation, and Detection of the NIH3T3 Cellular Response to Acidic Fibroblast Growth Factor (aFGF-1)
source_data.protocol_name: Complete Sample Protocol Detailing the Seeding, Stimulation, and Detection of the NIH3T3 Cellular Response to Acidic Fibroblast Growth Factor (aFGF-1)
source_data.protocol_name_html: Complete Sample Protocol Detailing the Seeding, Stimulation, and Detection of the NIH3T3 Cellular Response to Acidic Fibroblast Growth Factor (aFGF-1)
source_data.annotation:
No single blocking reagent will be optimal for every antigen-antibody pair. Some primary

antibodies may exhibit greatly reduced signal or different non-specific banding in different blocking solutions. If you have difficulty detecting your target protein, changing the blocking solution may dramatically improve performance. If the primary antibody has worked well in the past using chemiluminescent detection, try that blocking solution.
source_data.thread_text:
No single blocking reagent will be optimal for every antigen-antibody pair. Some primary

antibodies may exhibit greatly reduced signal or different non-specific banding in different blocking solutions. If you have difficulty detecting your target protein, changing the blocking solution may dramatically improve performance. If the primary antibody has worked well in the past using chemiluminescent detection, try that blocking solution.
source_data.body:
No single blocking reagent will be optimal for every antigen-antibody pair. Some primary

antibodies may exhibit greatly reduced signal or different non-specific banding in different blocking solutions. If you have difficulty detecting your target protein, changing the blocking solution may dramatically improve performance. If the primary antibody has worked well in the past using chemiluminescent detection, try that blocking solution.

source_data.thread_title: Annotation on step 24 of Complete Sample Protocol Detailing the Seeding, Stimulation, and Detection of the NIH3T3 Cellular Response to Acidic Fibroblast Growth Factor (aFGF-1)
source_data.protocol_name: Complete Sample Protocol Detailing the Seeding, Stimulation, and Detection of the NIH3T3 Cellular Response to Acidic Fibroblast Growth Factor (aFGF-1)
source_data.protocol_name_html: Complete Sample Protocol Detailing the Seeding, Stimulation, and Detection of the NIH3T3 Cellular Response to Acidic Fibroblast Growth Factor (aFGF-1)
source_data.annotation: Odyssey Blocking Buffer often yields higher and more consistent sensitivity and performance than other blockers. Nonfat dry milk or casein dissolved in PBS can also be used for blocking and antibody dilution. Milk-based reagents can interfere with detection when using anti-goat antibodies. They also deteriorate rapidly at 4 °C, so diluted antibodies cannot be kept and reused for more than a few days. If using casein, a 0.1% solution in 0.2 x PBS buffer is recommended (Hammersten-grade casein is not required).
source_data.thread_text: Odyssey Blocking Buffer often yields higher and more consistent sensitivity and performance than other blockers. Nonfat dry milk or casein dissolved in PBS can also be used for blocking and antibody dilution. Milk-based reagents can interfere with detection when using anti-goat antibodies. They also deteriorate rapidly at 4 °C, so diluted antibodies cannot be kept and reused for more than a few days. If using casein, a 0.1% solution in 0.2 x PBS buffer is recommended (Hammersten-grade casein is not required).
source_data.body: Odyssey Blocking Buffer often yields higher and more consistent sensitivity and performance than other blockers. Nonfat dry milk or casein dissolved in PBS can also be used for blocking and antibody dilution. Milk-based reagents can interfere with detection when using anti-goat antibodies. They also deteriorate rapidly at 4 °C, so diluted antibodies cannot be kept and reused for more than a few days. If using casein, a 0.1% solution in 0.2 x PBS buffer is recommended (Hammersten-grade casein is not required).

source_data.annotation: Blocking solutions containing BSA can be used, but in some cases may cause high membrane background. BSA-containing blockers are not generally recommended and should be used only when the primary antibody requires BSA as blocker.
source_data.thread_text: Blocking solutions containing BSA can be used, but in some cases may cause high membrane background. BSA-containing blockers are not generally recommended and should be used only when the primary antibody requires BSA as blocker.
source_data.body: Blocking solutions containing BSA can be used, but in some cases may cause high membrane background. BSA-containing blockers are not generally recommended and should be used only when the primary antibody requires BSA as blocker.

components.data: Allow blocking for 90 minutes at RT with moderate shaking on a rotator.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Allow blocking for 90 minutes at RT with moderate shaking on a rotator.

components.data:
Add the two primary antibodies to a tube containing Odyssey Blocking Buffer. Combine the solutions defined below for phospho-ERK target analysis, using total ERK2 for normalization:

  • Phospho-ERK (Rabbit; 1:100 dilution; Cell Signaling Technology P/N 9101)
  • Total ERK2 (Mouse; 1:100 dilution; Santa Cruz Biotechnology P/N SC-1647)
components.name: Description

source_data.description:
Add the two primary antibodies to a tube containing Odyssey Blocking Buffer. Combine the solutions defined below for phospho-ERK target analysis, using total ERK2 for normalization:

  • Phospho-ERK (Rabbit; 1:100 dilution; Cell Signaling Technology P/N 9101)
  • Total ERK2 (Mouse; 1:100 dilution; Santa Cruz Biotechnology P/N SC-1647)

components.data: Mix the primary antibody solution well before adding to wells.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Mix the primary antibody solution well before adding to wells.

components.data: Remove blocking buffer from the blocking step and add 50 μL of the desired primary antibody or antibodies in Odyssey Blocking Buffer to cover the bottom of each well.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Remove blocking buffer from the blocking step and add 50 μL of the desired primary antibody or antibodies in Odyssey Blocking Buffer to cover the bottom of each well.

components.data: Make sure to include control wells without primary antibody to serve as a source for back- ground well intensity. Add 50 μL of Odyssey Blocking Buffer to control wells only.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Make sure to include control wells without primary antibody to serve as a source for back- ground well intensity. Add 50 μL of Odyssey Blocking Buffer to control wells only.

source_data.title: Odyssey Blocking Buffer to control wells

components.data: Incubate with primary antibody overnight with gentle shaking at RT.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Incubate with primary antibody overnight with gentle shaking at RT.

components.data: Wash the plate five times with 1X PBS + 0.1% Tween® 20 for 5 minutes at RT with gentle shaking, using a generous amount of buffer. Detailed in steps 44-59.
components.name: Description

source_data.description: Wash the plate five times with 1X PBS + 0.1% Tween® 20 for 5 minutes at RT with gentle shaking, using a generous amount of buffer. Detailed in steps 44-59.

components.data: Using a multi-channel pipettor, add 200 μL of Tween Washing Solution (RT). Make sure to add the solution down the sides of the wells carefully to avoid detaching the cells from the well bottom. (wash 1/5)

components.data:
Dilute the fluorescently-labeled secondary antibody in Odyssey® Blocking Buffer as specified below. To lower background, add Tween 20 to the diluted antibody to a final concentration of 0.2%.

  • Goat anti-rabbit IRDye® 680RD (1:800 dilution)
  • Goat anti-mouse IRDye 800CW (1:800 dilution)
components.name: Description

source_data.description:

  • Goat anti-rabbit IRDye® 680RD (1:800 dilution)
  • Goat anti-mouse IRDye 800CW (1:800 dilution)

components.data: After final wash, remove wash solution completely from wells.Turn the plate upside down and tap or blot gently on paper towels to remove traces of wash buffer.
components.name: Description

components.data: Before plate scanning, clean the bottom plate surface and the Odyssey Imager scanning bed with moist, lint-free paper to avoid obstructions during scanning.
components.name: Description
